profiles:
Summary I am detail oriented. I am passionate about using computer science to solve complex problems in the most elegant ways possible. I enjoy designing large-scale systems to be efficient, extensible, and as easy to use as possible. 
 
I have a passion for helping people. I love working on projects which help or improve someone's life. Whether this is a game which helps people block out their problems in life for a few minutes of playing or a simple feature on a website which saves 10 seconds of time. Anything which improves someone's life is well worth any effort to design and build it. 
 
My two main objectives are completing what needs to get done when it needs to be done and to learn as much as I can while getting it there. I recognize the imperative importance in finishing a task by a certain deadline and I work as hard as I can to meet that deadline. If I have a little more time, I like to try and spend it approaching a problem with a more complicated approach that has better benefits, both for the learning experience and additional benefits the solution has. Experience Software Engineering Intern Google May 2015  – Present (3 months) Math and CS Tutor DigiPen Institute of Technology September 2013  –  April 2015  (1 year 8 months) I help students who need help with Mathematics in the courses of Linear Algebra; Differential and Integral Calculus; Differential Equations; and Discrete Mathematics. I also help students with ANSI C, C++, data structures, graphics programming, and algorithms. Software Engineering Intern Google May 2014  –  August 2014  (4 months) Santa Monica, CA Software Engineer Google Summer of Code 2013 June 2013  –  September 2013  (4 months) I created a unified, cross-platform meta-build system for Simple DirectMedia Layer 2.0. This was done using a modified version of Premake 5. The meta-build script provided build support with Visual Studio 2008, 2010, and 2012, Xcode 3 and 4, and GNU Makefiles on both Windows using MinGW and Linux (tested with Linux Mint). 
 
Blog detailing work: http://gsocben.blogspot.com/ Website Developer enove October 2011  –  July 2012  (10 months) I worked on backend website development, mostly in PHP with an IIS webserver and MySQL database. My work for backend development included implementing a session-based image management system for guaranteeing a user is not able to right click and download an image from a website for all web browsers compliant to web standards. Sped up image loading time by making use of automatically generated thumbnails of the huge larger images. 
 
I worked on frontend development. Implemented a slideshow for continuously displaying large-scale images using a cross-browser approach with jQuery (though not using jQuery's animation features). 
 
Implemented a steganography-based security system for imagess wherein all images were trackable for hidden copyright information so the website owner could verify legal ownership of copied property that wasn't altered too severely. Programmer Lakeland College January 2012  –  May 2012  (5 months) Collected information, URLs, and helped design which pages would be displayed on a mobile application to be used by Lakeland College students. Their existing application was being recreated by Blackboard, Inc. and I was working as a liaison between Lakeland College and Blackboard developers. I created a Java application to convert a database dump of Lakeland course information to a CSV file for Blackboard programmers to use within the application. Software Development Intern Google June 2013  –  September 2013  (4 months) Mountain View As an intern on the production kernel team, I designed and developed each of the following: 
• Memory allocator that raises alerts when memory is misused. It recognizes and provides safeguards against buffer overflows, forbidden memory access, and improper treatment of address alignment. 
• Memory validation tool retrieves information about a memory mapping containing a specific address for a specific process. 
• Routine that ingests sequential files while guaranteeing that parsing will occur as atomically as supported by the sequential file interface. 
• Routine that makes weighted choices based upon a probability distribution. 
 
I also developed an automated test suite that exercises the kernel's cryptographic key retention service, reproducing, patching, and documenting kernel vulnerabilities along the way.

Summary Programmer, leader, mentor, student.  
 
I interned at Microsoft in high school on the Translate Team, and started a Computer Science club at my high school which now keeps growing.  
 
Since then, I've interned at Google on the YouTube Desktop team, this summer I am back at Google on the Search Engine team, and in the fall I will be joining Facebook as an intern.  
 
I am a rising junior at the University of Washington, studying Computer Science. This past year I served the CSE community at my school as a Google Student Ambassador and ACM leader.  
 
In the meantime I enjoy interviewing, competing in hackathons, attending tech conferences, traveling, working on my own personal projects, speaking at tech events such as the Washington STEM Summit, serving as a leader on campus, mentoring other students who wish to pursue computer science, and just being a college student. 
 
I enjoy tackling tough technical challenges, learning new skills, and meeting inspirational people both in and out of the tech industry that motivate me to work hard and enjoy the ride :)

Summary I am interested in experimenting with as much of Computer Science as I can, in order to find the field that is best suited for me, in which I can make a difference. 
Also, I want to connect with as many people as I can. 
 
The topics that really interest me are Machine Learning and Web Technologies. 
 
During my bachelors studies at the Computer Science I have had the pleasure of working on some great projects as a student collaborator at Google Summer of Code (Speech Recognition software), as an intern at Google (YouTube and Developers Console) and as an intern at ARIA (Romanian Association for Artificial Intelligence). It has also been a pleasure to be a member of ROSEdu and help organize and take part in their activities. 
 
I am trying to learn as much as possible and have fun at the same time by participating in hackatons or reading online articles. 
 
The technologies and languages used in my studies and extracurricular activities are Java (+ Android), Javascript, Python and Linux Shell.
